choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

questions.text: A patient was injured with a rusted metal object. What is the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin in such cases?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibit the release of GABA and glycine

 

Tetanus toxin, also known as tetanospasmin, is produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani. When a person is injured by rusted metal, this bacterium can enter the body and produce the toxin. Tetanospasmin specifically targets the nervous system by binding to receptors on motor nerve terminals and getting internalized. It then travels retrogradely to the central nervous system where it inhibits the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons.

 

GABA and glycine normally function to inhibit motor neurons and prevent excessive muscle contraction. By blocking these neurotransmitters, tetanospasmin causes unopposed muscle contractions, leading to the characteristic muscle spasms and rigidity seen in tetanus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibit the release of Acetylcholine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit acetylcholine (Ach) release. Instead, botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum inhibits the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis rather than muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Inhibit the release of epinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not affect the release of epinephrine. Epinephrine release is primarily regulated by the adrenal glands and not significantly impacted by tetanospasmin.

 

Option D. Inhibit the release of norepinephrine: This is incorrect. Tetanus toxin does not inhibit the release of norepinephrine. Norepinephrine release is also regulated by different mechanisms and is not directly influenced by tetanospasmin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin) inhibits the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contractions and the characteristic spasms of tetanus.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: Delayed hypersensitivity is due to? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Interferon gamma

 

  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH) is a form of cell-mediated immune response that occurs typically 24-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. This response is primarily mediated by T-helper 1 (Th1) cells which secrete a variety of cytokines, including Interferon gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is crucial in activating macrophages and enhancing their microbicidal activity, which is a key component of the DTH response. This type of hypersensitivity is important in defense against intracellular pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) - IL-2 is primarily involved in the activation and proliferation of T cells but is not the primary mediator of delayed hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option C. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) - IL-12 plays a role in the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells and can promote IFN-γ production, but it is not the direct mediator of DTH.

 

Option D. Interleukin-4 (IL-4) - IL-4 is associated with the differentiation of naive T cells into Th2 cells and promotes humoral immunity, which is not involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interferon gamma is the key cytokine responsible for mediating delayed hypersensitivity reactions by activating macrophages and enhancing their pathogen-killing capabilities.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is typically cultured in which medium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lowenstein-Jensen medium

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires a special medium for growth and cannot grow on routine culture media. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard and most commonly used medium for culturing M. tuberculosis. This medium contains:

 

  • Coagulated egg proteins
  • Glycerol
  • Asparagine
  • Potato flour
  • Mineral salts: The medium provides essential nutrients and supports the slow growth of mycobacteria over 3-8 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macconkey agar: Incorrect 

 

  • This medium is used for growing and differentiating Gram-negative enteric bacteria
  • It contains bile salts and crystal violet which inhibit Gram-positive bacteria
  • M. tuberculosis cannot grow on this medium

 

Option C. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a selective medium used for isolating fungi
  • Its acidic pH and high glucose concentration make it unsuitable for bacterial growth
  • M. tuberculosis requires more complex nutrients not present in this medium

 

Option D. Mueller-Hinton agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a non-selective medium primarily used for antibiotic susceptibility testing
  • It lacks the specific nutrients required for mycobacterial growth
  • The growth time required by M. tuberculosis is too long for this medium

 

Educational Objective: 

 

M. tuberculosis requires specific growth conditions and must be cultured on Lowenstein-Jensen medium, which provides the necessary nutrients for its slow growth over several weeks.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioides immitis exists as spherules filled with endospores in tissue, not as budding yeast. It is endemic to the southwestern United States, especially Arizona and California.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: A traveler consumed oysters. He later presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting. The organism seen on microscopy exhibited Kanagawa phenomenon. The likely causative organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a salt-loving organism commonly associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw or undercooked oysters. It can cause gastroenteritis characterized by symptoms like watery or bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The Kanagawa phenomenon, which is the hemolysis of human red blood cells on a special medium, is specifically linked with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, further confirming its presence in this case. This bacterium's name also hints at its association with blood ("hemolyticus"), which aligns with the symptoms of bloody diarrhea seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: This organism typically causes food poisoning with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, but it is not associated with bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not specifically related to seafood.

 

Option B. Salmonella typhi: This organism causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and constipation or diarrhea, but not typically bloody diarrhea or the Kanagawa phenomenon. It is also not linked with seafood consumption or being salt-loving.

 

Option D. Vibrio cholera: While Vibrio cholera is associated with severe watery diarrhea, it does not cause bloody diarrhea or present with the Kanagawa phenomenon. Vibrio cholera also differs from Vibrio parahaemolyticus in its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the likely cause of gastroenteritis with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of oysters, and it exhibits the Kanagawa phenomenon on microscopy.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the genital area and a painful vesicle on examination, accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HSV2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) typically presents with painful genital vesicles and can cause painful lymphadenopathy. HSV2 is a common cause of genital herpes and is known for causing recurrent outbreaks of painful vesicular lesions in the genital area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molluscum: Molluscum contagiosum causes painless, pearly papules, which are typically umbilicated. These lesions are not vesicular and do not cause painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. HPV: Human Papillomavirus infection results in the formation of warts, which are generally painless. HPV warts can appear on the genital area but do not present with vesicles or painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. HIV: Human Immunodeficiency Virus does not present with genital vesicles. HIV infection leads to systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy, rather than localized painful vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:


HSV2 infection is characterized by painful genital vesicles and can be associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool is given below. Identify the causative organism? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptosporidium

 

Cryptosporidium is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The image provided shows the characteristic appearance of Cryptosporidium oocysts, which are typically detected in stool samples using staining techniques.

 

Cryptosporidium:

 

  • Transmission: Typically occurs through ingestion of contaminated water or food.
  • Symptoms: Includes persistent diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. In immunocompromised patients, the diarrhea can be severe and lead to significant dehydration and weight loss.
  • Diagnosis: The diagnosis is confirmed by microscopic examination of stool samples. Special stains such as modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (kinoun stain) can be used to visualize the oocysts, which appear as round, red-stained structures against a blue or green background.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Another coccidian parasite causing diarrhea, but the oocysts are larger than those of Cryptosporidium and require different staining techniques (such as modified acid-fast stain) for identification.

 

Option C. Microspora: Refers to microsporidia, which are also known to cause diarrhea in HIV patients. However, they appear as small spores and require specific staining techniques like Chromotrope 2R or calcofluor white stain.

 

Option D. Cystoisospora (formerly Isospora): Causes isosporiasis, another diarrheal illness in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts are larger and ellipsoidal, detected using acid-fast staining methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with persistent diarrhea, Cryptosporidium is a common causative organism, identified by its characteristic oocysts in stool samples stained with special stains like the kinoun stain.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

Explanation:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (also known as erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is mediated by a Type III hypersensitivity reaction. In this type of reaction:

 

  • Immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • This reaction occurs in lepromatous leprosy due to a sudden increase in circulating Mycobacterium leprae antigens that form immune complexes with antibodies.
  • The immune complexes cause tissue damage, resulting in tender erythematous nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation.
  • Key Features of Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • Immune complex-mediated (IgG or IgM antibodies bind to soluble antigens).
  • Complement activation and neutrophilic inflammation.
  • Examples: Type 2 lepra reaction, serum sickness, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Type I Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Mediated by IgE antibodies, causing mast cell degranulation.
  • Seen in allergic reactions, anaphylaxis, and atopic conditions (e.g., urticaria, asthma).

 

Option B) Type II Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Involves cytotoxic antibodies (IgG or IgM) binding to cell-bound antigens, leading to cell destruction via complement or ADCC (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples: Hemolytic anemia, Goodpasture syndrome, Rh incompatibility.

 

Option D) Type IV Hypersensitivity:

 

  • Cell-mediated immunity involving T-lymphocytes and macrophages.
  • Delayed onset (48-72 hours) and seen in tuberculin skin tests, contact dermatitis, and granuloma formation.
  • Type I lepra reaction (reversal reaction) is an example of Type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum) is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction caused by immune complex deposition. It presents with tender nodules, fever, and systemic inflammation and is commonly associated with lepromatous leprosy.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.
